Making a dungeon: HTML

Introduction to HTML

Back when the web was first created, it was entirely used for displaying documents that consisted largely of text. HTML (HyperText Markup Language) was created as a way to structure documents so web browsers would know how to display them.

Nearly every web page you load today still uses HTML. All HTML consists of various elements, which are tag names wrapped in < and >. Element and tag will be used somewhat interchangeably throughout this document, and the difference is mostly semantic.

  • tags refer exclusively to the opening and closing pieces. For example, a paragraph tag is <p>. There are opening tags (<p>) and closing tags (</p>), which denote the beginning and end of an element.
  • elements refer to the entire block in the document, including the content. A paragraph element may be <p>This is a paragaph element.</p>, which includes both the opening and closing tags.

There are several types of tags that are self-closing, which means that they don't have a closing tag. One example of this is an image (<img>). An image tag has it's content contained within the tag itself, in the form a src attribute.

Attributes

In addition to content, as with the paragraph above, HTML elements can also have attributes. An attribute will impart some further meaning or context to the HTML element. For example, the <img> tag above could be given a src attribute, which tells the document what image to load. A full image element might look like <img src="https://example.com/image.jpg">, which would load the image from example.com. It doesn't make sense for an image to have any other content, so it closes itself.

Attributes can also be used to add specific stylings to elements, which we'll see later. Some other types of tags that we may encounter are:

  • <p>: Paragraph
  • <a>: Anchor, which contain links
  • <ul>: An unordered list
  • <li>: An element in a list
  • <table>: A table

These elements can be nested inside one another to create complex structures. You can think of a basic HTML document the same way you would a Microsoft Word document. If you were writing an essay, you might end up with something like:

<body>
    <h1>My Essay</h1>
    <p>Introduction paragraph <a>Link to source number 1</a>.</p>
</body>

Back to the Game

For our purposes we'll be using HTML to layout the world of our game. Our game characters need a place to run around, so let's start by building a big, empty room. Our world is going to essentially be a grid, where the characters can step through each individual square in the grid to move around. See figure 1-1, where our character is represented by C that can move to any adjacent square. For our purposes, we'll be using a <table> tag. Let's make a 10x10 table to match the figure, where each row of the grid is marked by a table row (<tr>) and each cell of the grid is marked by a table cell (<td>. As a quick note, I'm not going to provide an HTML reference for you. If you have any questions about how a particular type of element works, the MDN has a great resource for it.

For now, open up a new file in your favorite text editor and insert a table element with 10 rows. Each row should have 10 columns.

<tr> represents a table row, so there will be 10 of those. <td> is a table cell, and each row will have 10 cells nested inside of it. There also a <tbody>, which is the body of the table. Tables can also be given a heading, but we don't need that. We'll also put a . inside all of the table cells so we can see where the grid is.
